body: I fixed this typo a while ago.
Also, PLEASE tell me if I'm doing something stupid. lol

... and I do realize the primitive scheduler I've put in place is an "execute until done" sort of scheduler. Meaning it doesn't provide gaps for other code execution. This is a bare-metal simplistic impl. I think for most browser-based use cases, adding gaps ala MicroTask scheduling probably isn't completely necessary because the event stream sources themselves will be async, but there's definitely a need for that type of scheduler.
@blesh sounds like you meant to provide a link to the code, no?
Thanks, Jeff
Heh... yeah I got a little lazy there. Thank you Victor.
Closing this for now. I feel like the Scheduling is in an okay place.
This has been done

fixed... also added jshint (finally): https://github.com/ReactiveX/RxJS/commit/19c164ac864c8984f86181ddc6ad2f0d225684d8
Thank you so much for this pull request. I wasn't able to merge this one, directly, and I had to make those changes anyhow after updating BabelJS.

This was discussed quite a bit. The goal, long term, is to produce files for ES6 modules, AMD, CJS, as well as ES5 globals... Since ES6 is a subset of TypeScript, it should "just work" to import ES6 modules.

As a matter of personal taste, I'm not a huge fan of having to maintain interfaces, but I'm not the only one working on this project (even though I have the lion's share of commits right now). It's a team effort, especially in terms of design. If the folks responsible for helping me design this implementation decide it would be best to convert to TypeScript, I'm 100% on board.

For now, though, I'm going to close this issue because I know what the result of the last discussion was.

(Closing obviously doesn't end the discussion)

I think the plan for ES5/ES3 will be to output AMD and CJS modules, as well as some "Globally" registered files that contain subsets of the operators/functionality. Similar to RxJS 2 with `lite`, `all`, etc.

I know that @trxcllnt has some ideas around this, and so does @jhusain...

> Thank you so much for this pull request. I wasn't able to merge this one, directly, and I had to make those changes anyhow after updating BabelJS.

okay!
I see. Thank you!

Observables are referentially transparent, so they can be optionally async. If you encapsulate all state within the Observable operators, your code will work the same whether it runs synchronously or asynchronously.

Promises (etc.) force asynchrony because they are stateful. This is sometimes called [Releasing Zalgo](http://blog.izs.me/post/59142742143/designing-apis-for-asynchrony), and is a problem people encounter when they write programs that rely on mutable external state.

One solution is to always force asynchrony (at the cost of performance). The other (and better imo) solution is to write code that doesn't rely on side-effects.
Hey, Paul. I don't see why promises are stateful and, let's say, hot observables are not. Can you expand on that?

You're right, hot Observables are the definition of stateful. Most side-effects can still be encapsulated inside the Monad and multicast correctly, but if not, you can always switch to subscribing (or observing) on an asynchronous scheduler at that point.
Makes sense.

I work on a tool that is useful for exactly this purpose, will transpile your es6 code to AMD, CommonJS and Global builds. http://stealjs.com/docs/steal-tools.export.html  I agree with @gaearon that doing this as a pre-publish step is usually the best  way to go.  I could submit a PR that includes a build script if you'd like to take a look at it, should be pretty simple.
What does Steal use for transpilation? The momentum behind Babel is incredible, does Steal use it?
You can use either Babel or Traceur.

Currently I'm using Babel and Broccoli. But the whole thing needs work. I'm open to any solution, but I can't guarantee I'll use said solution. Speed, ergonomics and extensibility are pretty important.

Ultimately I may even use Rx to build itself?

I think this is for the next versions of Rx\* coming out. I don't believe this versions are out in the general public. You should stick to document found at Reactive-Extentions and http://reactivex.io/
Actually, this is going to break tests, @vsavkin and @jeffbcross ... because I changed where the global was installing to Rx3.Observable ... Ideally, it will be Rx.Observable at some point...
